Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Story: I stood in the kitchen, my mother’s voice echoing from the living room as she reminded me, again, that I was to lead the family’s annual ancestor ceremony this evening. It was my turn, she said, to honor our traditions, to show respect and keep our family’s values alive. I could see the pride in her eyes, the hope that I would not let her down. But my phone buzzed in my pocket—another alert from the factory. The machines I was responsible for had missed their last service window, and now a few were running dangerously hot. If I didn’t get there soon, we could be facing a costly breakdown, maybe even a safety hazard. My supervisor’s text was blunt: “We need you now.” I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, my family’s expectations on one side, my professional duty on the other. My heart pounded as I stared at the family altar, then at my work boots by the door, torn between the two parts of myself that everyone seemed to need at the same time.
